poem:
Title: "Truth's Flame in Unholy Depths"

In the pit of despair, she stands,
Iran's pledge, unsilenced in chains.
Qarchak's lament, the world's guilt.
Hell she tells, of parched lips
and tortured whispers, of her nine moons;
It is not rage, but truth's flame that scorches,
In the prison echo, in the hijab's hem -
Unquenchable, undeterred; Nasrin remains.
With a courage beyond thirst, she proclaims,
"I am ready to return."
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I am ready to return whenever they say’: Nasrin Sotoudeh on prison, the hijab, and violence in Iran Iran’s Qarchak jail has been called many things: a torture chamber; the worst women’s prison in the world; unfit for humans. Nasrin Sotoudeh uses just one word to describe the nine months she spent there: “Hell.” Sotoudeh does not speak of the appalling conditions or stench of sewage, the undrinkable water or lack of food, the disease". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
